stages.description: Dividing a metre stick into 10 equal sections using masking tape, handling fraction strips cut into tenths, and counting physical tenth-pieces to build whole quantities
resources: metre stick with masking tape markers
Cuisenaire orange rods (as tenths of a Cuisenaire ten-rod)
stages.example_activity: Mark a metre stick into 10 equal sections with tape. Each section is one tenth of a metre (10 cm). Pick up 3 sections of fraction strip: you have 3/10. Count in tenths along the metre stick: 1/10, 2/10... 10/10 = 1 whole. Keep counting: 11/10, 12/10... What is 14/10 in wholes and tenths?
stages.transition_cue: Child counts in tenths fluently past 1 whole and states that 10/10 = 1 without needing the physical strips

stages.description: Drawing number lines marked in tenths, shading fraction bars divided into 10 equal parts, and recording tenths as fractions on paper
stages.example_activity: Draw a number line from 0 to 2, marking every tenth. Place 7/10 on the line. Place 13/10 on the line. Now shade 6 parts of a fraction bar divided into 10: write 6/10. What division gives you this? 6 ÷ 10 = 6/10.
stages.transition_cue: Child places any number of tenths on a number line (including beyond 1) and connects tenths to division by 10 without the drawn bar

stages.description: Working with tenths mentally, connecting division by 10 to tenths, and counting in tenths across whole number boundaries
stages.example_activity: What is 4 ÷ 10? What is 15/10 as a mixed number? Count in tenths from 8/10 to 14/10. If I have 23/10, how many wholes and how many tenths?
stages.transition_cue: Child converts between tenths and wholes mentally, stating division-by-10 results as tenths without hesitation

stages.description: Finding unit fractions of sets by physically sharing counters into equal groups, and using fraction circles and fraction strips to show one equal part of a whole
stages.example_activity: Find 1/3 of 12 counters: share them equally into 3 sorting trays. How many in one tray? 4. So 1/3 of 12 = 4. Now take a fraction circle cut into 5 equal pieces. Hold up 1 piece: that is 1/5. Compare the size of 1/3 and 1/5 pieces — which is bigger?
stages.transition_cue: Child finds unit fractions of sets by dividing and compares unit fraction pieces, saying 'Bigger denominator means smaller pieces'

stages.description: Using a fraction wall to compare unit fractions, placing unit fractions on a number line between 0 and 1, and drawing fraction bars to find unit fractions of quantities
stages.example_activity: Look at the fraction wall. Line up the 1/3 bar and the 1/5 bar. Which is longer? 1/3. Place 1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/5 and 1/8 on a number line from 0 to 1. Draw a fraction bar of 20 squares split into 5 groups: 1/5 of 20 = 4.
stages.transition_cue: Child orders any set of unit fractions from smallest to largest and finds unit fractions of quantities using division without the fraction wall

stages.description: Comparing and ordering unit fractions mentally, finding unit fractions of quantities by division, and explaining why larger denominators give smaller fractions
stages.example_activity: Order from smallest to largest: 1/2, 1/8, 1/5, 1/3. Find 1/6 of 30. Explain why 1/4 is greater than 1/6.
stages.transition_cue: Child instantly orders unit fractions and explains the inverse relationship between denominator size and fraction size

stages.description: Finding non-unit fractions of sets by first sharing counters into equal groups (unit fraction) then taking multiple groups, using fraction circles to show several parts shaded
stages.example_activity: Find 3/4 of 20 counters. First share 20 into 4 equal groups: 5 in each. Take 3 groups: 3 × 5 = 15. So 3/4 of 20 = 15. Now use fraction circles: take 3 out of 4 quarter-pieces. How much of the whole do you have?
stages.transition_cue: Child consistently finds the unit fraction first, then multiplies by the numerator, verbalising: 'I divide by the bottom, then multiply by the top'

stages.description: Drawing fraction bars to find non-unit fractions of quantities, shading the correct number of parts, and placing non-unit fractions on a number line
stages.example_activity: Draw a bar of 24 squares divided into 8 equal groups (3 squares each). Shade 5 groups for 5/8 of 24: 5 × 3 = 15. Place 5/8 on a number line. Is 5/8 more or less than 1/2?
stages.transition_cue: Child draws fraction bars and calculates non-unit fractions without needing counters, and places non-unit fractions accurately on number lines

stages.description: Finding non-unit fractions of quantities mentally using the divide-then-multiply strategy, and reasoning about what fraction remains
stages.example_activity: Find 2/5 of 35. Find 3/8 of 40. Sam eats 2/3 of 18 grapes — how many are left? What fraction is left?
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates non-unit fractions of quantities within 5 seconds and reasons about complementary fractions without visual support

stages.description: Folding paper strips to discover equivalent fractions physically: folding in half then folding again to see that 1/2 = 2/4, using fraction circles and fraction strips to overlay and compare
resources: fraction strips (halves, thirds, quarters, sixths, eighths)
stages.example_activity: Fold a paper strip in half — mark 1/2. Fold it in half again — now you have quarters. How many quarters fill the same space as 1/2? Two quarters. So 1/2 = 2/4. Now fold once more to get eighths: 1/2 = 4/8. Overlay a 1/3 fraction strip on 2/6 strips — do they match?
stages.transition_cue: Child finds equivalent fractions by folding or overlaying and states the equivalence without being prompted (e.g. 'That's the same as 2/4')

stages.description: Using a fraction wall to identify equivalent fractions by lining up bars, and drawing diagrams to show that multiplying numerator and denominator by the same number produces equal fractions
stages.example_activity: On the fraction wall, find all fractions equivalent to 1/2: look for bars that line up exactly. Record: 1/2 = 2/4 = 3/6 = 4/8. Draw a bar split into 3 with 2 shaded (2/3). Draw another bar split into 6 with 4 shaded (4/6). Are they the same amount? Yes: 2/3 = 4/6.
stages.transition_cue: Child generates equivalent fractions by multiplying top and bottom by the same number and checks using a diagram

stages.description: Generating equivalent fractions by multiplying or dividing numerator and denominator by the same number, and recognising equivalence without diagrams
stages.example_activity: Write two fractions equivalent to 3/4. Simplify 6/8. Fill in the missing number: 2/? = 6/9. Is 4/6 equivalent to 2/3? Explain how you know.
stages.transition_cue: Child generates and simplifies equivalent fractions mentally, explaining the multiplicative relationship between numerator and denominator

stages.description: Adding and subtracting same-denominator fractions using fraction strips: physically combining and removing fraction pieces, counting the resulting parts
stages.example_activity: Take 3 fifth-strips and 2 more fifth-strips. How many fifths altogether? 3/5 + 2/5 = 5/5 = 1 whole. Now start with 5 eighth-pieces from a fraction circle. Remove 2 pieces: 5/8 − 2/8 = 3/8. Did the size of each piece change? No — still eighths.
stages.transition_cue: Child adds and subtracts same-denominator fractions with strips, consistently keeping the denominator the same and saying: 'The pieces don't change size, I just count more or fewer'

stages.description: Using fraction bars and number lines to show same-denominator addition and subtraction, recording the calculation alongside the diagram
stages.example_activity: Draw a bar split into 7 parts. Shade 3 parts red, then 2 parts blue. Write: 3/7 + 2/7 = 5/7. On a number line marked in eighths, start at 6/8 and jump back 4/8. Where do you land? 2/8. Write the subtraction.
stages.transition_cue: Child records same-denominator fraction calculations correctly alongside diagrams and explains why only numerators are added or subtracted

stages.description: Adding and subtracting same-denominator fractions mentally, explaining the reasoning: 'Sevenths plus sevenths equals sevenths — like apples plus apples equals apples'
stages.example_activity: 3/9 + 5/9? 7/8 − 3/8? If I add 2/6 + 3/6 + 1/6, what do I get? Explain why 4/5 + 1/5 = 5/5 = 1 whole.
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates same-denominator fraction additions and subtractions instantly, never adding the denominators, and explains the reasoning using the 'counting units' analogy

stages.description: Comparing fractions by physically holding up fraction pieces side by side: unit fraction pieces to see which is bigger, and same-denominator fraction groups to see which has more
stages.example_activity: Hold up a 1/3 piece and a 1/5 piece from fraction circles. Which is bigger? 1/3. Why? Fewer pieces in the whole means each piece is bigger. Now take 3 eighth-strips and 5 eighth-strips. Which group is bigger? 5/8 — more of the same-sized pieces.
stages.transition_cue: Child compares fractions using pieces and states the rule: 'For unit fractions, smaller denominator means bigger piece; for same denominators, bigger numerator means bigger fraction'

stages.description: Using a fraction wall and number lines to compare and order fractions, drawing arrows or markers to show relative positions
stages.example_activity: Use the fraction wall to compare 1/4 and 1/6 — which bar is longer? Place 2/7, 5/7 and 1/7 on a number line. Order them from smallest to largest. Draw a fraction wall comparison for 3/8 and 5/8.
stages.transition_cue: Child places fractions on a number line and orders them correctly without checking against the fraction wall

stages.description: Comparing and ordering fractions mentally, selecting the correct comparison strategy (unit fraction rule vs same-denominator rule) and justifying each comparison
stages.example_activity: Which is greater: 1/3 or 1/8? Which is greater: 4/9 or 7/9? Order from smallest to largest: 1/6, 1/2, 1/4, 1/10. Is 3/5 greater or less than 1/2? Explain your reasoning.
stages.transition_cue: Child selects the correct comparison strategy without prompting, orders any set of unit fractions or same-denominator fractions instantly, and uses benchmark fractions like 1/2 to compare
